log.content: Create me a website about 3d printers. Make it technical and informative, including information such as calibration, what process should be followed after changing filament etc. Add lots of detail and use a modern design language with the main color being orange. You should create multiple pages, but make sure the main page is available in index.html

create_file
function.arguments:
{"filename":"calibration.html","content":" Calibration | 3D Printing Hub

3D Printing Hub

  • Home
  • Calibration
  • Filament Change
  • Troubleshooting

Precise Calibration

1. Bed Leveling

Manual leveling or automatic bed leveling (ABL) ensures the first layer adheres properly. For manual leveling, use a piece of paper to gauge the distance between nozzle and bed across multiple points.

  • Heat bed to printing temperature.
  • Disable steppers and move nozzle to each corner and center.
  • Adjust bed screws until paper slides with slight resistance.

2. Extruder E-Step Calibration

Ensuring your extruder feeds the correct filament length is critical for accurate prints and preventing over/under extrusion. 


M92 E100   ; Set current E-step to 100
M82        ; Use absolute distances for extrusion
G1 E100 F100 ; Extrude 100mm of filament at 100mm/min
; Measure actual extruded length and calculate:
; (Set E-steps * 100) / actual_extrusion_mm = new E-step value
M92 E[new_value] ; Set new E-step
M500     ; Save to EEPROM

3. Flow Rate and Temperature Tuning

Print a single-wall calibration cube and measure wall thickness to adjust flow rate. Fine-tune temperature by printing a temperature tower to find optimal settings for your filament.

  1. Print a 20mm cube with one perimeter.
  2. Measure wall thickness with calipers.
  3. Adjust flow rate: new_flow = (desired_thickness / measured_thickness) * current_flow.
  4. Print temperature tower with 5°C increments.

© 2023 3D Printing Hub. All rights reserved.

"}

function.arguments:
{"filename":"filament.html","content":" Filament Change | 3D Printing Hub

3D Printing Hub

  • Home
  • Calibration
  • Filament Change
  • Troubleshooting

Filament Change Workflow

1. Pre-Extraction Checks

  • Heat nozzle to printing temperature of the current filament.
  • Retract filament slowly to avoid breakage or grinding.
  • Inspect extruder gears for debris and clean if necessary.

2. Remove Old Filament

  1. Set temperature: e.g., 200°C for PLA, 240°C for ABS.
  2. Use extrusion menu to retract filament by 100mm at 100mm/min.
  3. Gently pull filament out by hand once retraction completes.

3. Insert New Filament

  1. Trim the filament at a 45° angle to ensure a clean tip.
  2. Feed filament until you see consistent extrusion at set temperature.
  3. Check for air gaps, stringing, or under-extrusion in the first layer.

4. Purge and Prime

Purge at least 50mm of filament to clear remnants of the previous filament. Use G-code: 


G92 E0        ; Reset extruder position
G1 E50 F100   ; Extrude 50mm of filament at 100mm/min
G92 E0        ; Reset extruder position

5. Fine-Tuning

Print a small test model (e.g., 20mm cube) to confirm optimal settings. Adjust temperature and flow rate as needed.

© 2023 3D Printing Hub. All rights reserved.

"}

function.arguments:
{"filename":"troubleshooting.html","content":" Troubleshooting | 3D Printing Hub

3D Printing Hub

  • Home
  • Calibration
  • Filament Change
  • Troubleshooting

Troubleshooting Common Issues

1. Stringing/Oozing

High stringing can result from excessive temperature or insufficient retraction.

  • Lower nozzle temperature in 5°C increments.
  • Increase retraction distance by 1-2mm.
  • Enable combing in slicer settings.

2. Under-Extrusion

Causes include clogged nozzle, incorrect E-steps, or filament diameter mismatch.

  1. Perform cold pull to clean nozzle.
  2. Recalibrate E-steps.
  3. Verify filament diameter in slicer matches actual diameter.

3. Layer Adhesion Issues

Poor adhesion between layers can weaken the part.

  • Increase print temperature by 5-10°C.
  • Slow down print speed by 10-20%.
  • Ensure proper cooling (for PLA, use 100% fan speed, for ABS, minimal cooling).

4. Warping

Warping often occurs due to uneven cooling or poor bed adhesion.

  • Use brim or raft.
  • Increase bed temperature by 5-10°C.
  • Apply adhesion aids: glue stick, hairspray, or PEI sheet.

© 2023 3D Printing Hub. All rights reserved.

"}
